mindset.heading: Your Programs Can Save and Load Data

components.content: You're about to learn **working with files** — how to read from and write to text files in Python. Until now, everything your programs used lived in memory and disappeared when the program ended. With file I/O, you can save data to disk, load it back, share it with other programs, and build tools that persist information.
Every expert programmer uses files: configs, logs, reports, and data. Once you master file I/O, you'll build programs that matter — from simple note-takers to tools that process real data.

You already know how to:
- Use strings, variables, and loops
- Define and call functions
- Work with lists and other collections

Everything so far lived **in memory**. Now you'll use **files** — data stored on disk. Your programs will open a file, read or write its contents (often as strings or lines), and close it. You'll combine file I/O with the skills you already have.

**File I/O** (input/output) means reading data from files and writing data to files. Python gives you a simple pattern: **open** a file (you get a file object), **read** or **write** using that object, then **close** it so the system can release resources. For text files, you work with strings and lines — the same types you already use.

**Real-World Examples:**

• **Config files** — Programs read settings from a .txt or .ini file so you can change behavior without editing code.
• **Logs** — Applications append lines to a log file to record what happened (errors, events, user actions).
• **CSV-like data** — Spreadsheet data or lists saved as lines; read them, process with loops, write results back.
• **Notes and to-do lists** — Save and load plain text so data persists between runs.
• **Save data** — Games or tools save progress (e.g., scores, state) to a file and load it next time.
• **Reports** — Generate a text report and write it to a file for sharing or printing.
• **Templates** — Read a template file, fill in values, write the result to a new file.

**Visual Metaphors:**

**File as a notebook** — You open it (open), read a page or the whole thing (read), write on a page (write), then close it (close). Until you close, other programs might not see your changes or you might tie up the file.

**Reading as a cursor** — When you read, Python moves a "cursor" through the file. read() gets everything from the cursor to the end; readline() gets one line; readlines() gets all lines as a list. After a full read(), the cursor is at the end, so another read() returns an empty string.

**Writing as appending or overwriting** — You can open for writing ("w" — creates or overwrites) or appending ("a" — adds to the end). Choosing the right mode prevents accidentally wiping data.

**Why closing and `with` matter:** If you open a file and never close it, the program may hold the file open (other programs can't change it, and buffers might not be written to disk). Python's **with** statement opens the file, lets you use it, and **automatically closes** it when the block ends — even if an error occurs. Professional code almost always uses `with` for files.

**Connection to prior knowledge:** You already use strings — file contents are strings (or lists of strings for lines). You already use loops — you'll loop over lines. You already use functions — you'll write functions that take a path and return file contents, or write data to a file. File I/O is the next step: same data types, new source and destination.

# Pattern you'll learn: open → use → close
with open("notes.txt", "r") as f:
    text = f.read()
# file is closed automatically
print(text)

components.content:
You've learned **what file I/O is** and **why it matters** — persistence, sharing data, automation.

**Why this matters:** Programs that read and write files are more useful and realistic.

**How you'll use this:** You'll learn the vocabulary — **open()**, **file object**, **file mode**, **read()**, **readlines()**, **write()**, **close()**, **with**, **path** — and then how they work together. Next: the terms and syntax for working with files.
You're moving from the idea of file I/O to the specific vocabulary. Right now you're learning the terms and syntax that will let you open, read, write, and close files confidently.

From Stage 0, you know that file I/O means reading from and writing to text files, and that we open, use, then close. Now you'll learn the precise terms: open(), file object, file mode, read(), readline(), readlines(), write(), writelines(), close(), with statement, path, and newline.

**open()** — Built-in function that opens a file and returns a file object. Example: open("data.txt", "r"). When it matters: First step for any file I/O. Connection: Takes a path and optional mode; use with for automatic close.

**file object** — The value returned by open(). You call read(), write(), close() on it. Example: f = open("x.txt"); f.read(). When it matters: This is your handle to the file. Connection: Use it only inside the with block or remember to close().

**file mode** — String that tells open() how to use the file. "r" = read (default), "w" = write (creates or overwrites), "a" = append (add to end). Example: open("log.txt", "a"). When it matters: Wrong mode causes errors or data loss. Connection: "r" requires file to exist; "w" and "a" create if missing.

**read()** — Method on a file object; returns the entire file contents as one string. Example: content = f.read(). When it matters: Use for small files or when you need the whole text. Connection: After read(), cursor is at end; another read() returns "".

**readline()** — Method that returns one line (including newline) or "" at end. Example: line = f.readline(). When it matters: Process a file line by line without loading all into memory. Connection: Repeated calls read successive lines.

**readlines()** — Method that returns a list of lines (each includes newline). Example: lines = f.readlines(). When it matters: Get all lines as a list for looping or processing. Connection: Like read() but split into lines.

**write()** — Method that writes a string to the file. Does not add a newline automatically. Example: f.write("hello"). When it matters: Use "w" or "a" mode; add \n for new lines. Connection: writelines() writes a list of strings.

**writelines()** — Method that writes a list of strings to the file; does not add newlines. Example: f.writelines(["a
", "b
"]). When it matters: Write multiple lines at once. Connection: You must include 
 in each string if you want line breaks.

**close()** — Method that closes the file and releases resources. Example: f.close(). When it matters: If you don't use with, you must close() to avoid leaks and ensure data is written. Connection: with closes automatically.

**with statement** — Context manager: with open(path, mode) as f: ... ensures the file is closed when the block ends. Example: with open("x.txt") as f: print(f.read()). When it matters: Best practice for files; safe even on errors. Connection: Use instead of manual open/close when possible.

**path** — Location of the file. Relative path is relative to current working directory (e.g. "data.txt"); absolute path is full (e.g. "C:\\Users\\You\\data.txt" on Windows). When it matters: Wrong path causes FileNotFoundError. Connection: open(path) uses this.

**newline** — The character (or two) that ends a line (\\n in Python). When it matters: readline() and readlines() include it; write() does not add it — add \n yourself. Connection: Without \n, write() puts everything on one line.

components.content:
You've learned the vocabulary: **open()**, **file object**, **file mode**, **read()**, **readline()**, **readlines()**, **write()**, **writelines()**, **close()**, **with**, **path**, **newline**.

**Why this matters:** Knowing the terms is the first step. Now you'll understand **how** Python opens a file, reads (moving a cursor), writes, and closes — and why with and mode choice matter.

**How you'll use this:** Next, you'll see the step-by-step process behind file I/O so you can use it correctly and fix problems.
You're moving from knowing the terms to understanding **how** file I/O actually works: what happens when you open, how reading moves a cursor, why close and with matter, and how paths are resolved.
You know the vocabulary: open(), file object, modes, read(), readlines(), write(), close(), with, path. Now you'll see how Python uses these when you open, read, write, or close a file.

**Step 1: open(path, mode)** — Python finds the file at the given path (relative to current directory or absolute). It creates a file object and prepares it for reading or writing based on mode. If the file doesn't exist and mode is "r", you get FileNotFoundError; with "w" or "a", Python creates the file if needed.

**Step 2: Mode determines behavior** — "r" (read): you can only read; file must exist. "w" (write): creates or **overwrites** the file; previous content is lost. "a" (append): creates or opens and **adds** at the end; existing content stays.

**Step 3: Reading moves a cursor** — The file object has an internal position. read() returns everything from that position to the end and moves the cursor to the end. readline() returns one line (including \n) and moves the cursor to the next line. readlines() reads all remaining lines into a list. After a full read(), another read() returns an empty string.

**Step 4: read() vs readline() vs readlines()** — read() → one string (whole file). readline() → one line per call. readlines() → list of lines (each usually ends with \n). For line-by-line processing without loading all: use for line in f: (or readline() in a loop). For small files, read() or readlines() is fine.

**Step 5: write() and newlines** — write(s) writes the string s to the file. It does **not** add a newline. So write("line1"); write("line2") puts "line1line2" in the file. You must add 
: write("line1
"); write("line2
"). writelines(list) writes each string in the list; again, include 
 in each if you want line breaks.

**Step 6: Why close() matters** — Data may be buffered in memory; close() flushes buffers and releases the file so other programs can use it. If you don't close, long-running programs can leak resources, and on some systems your writes might not appear until close.

**Step 7: What with does** — with open(path, mode) as f: ... runs the block with f as the file object. When the block ends (normally or by exception), Python automatically calls f.close(). So you never forget to close, and you avoid leaks and incomplete writes.

**Step 8: Relative vs absolute path** — Relative path (e.g. "data.txt") is relative to the **current working directory** (where you ran the script). Absolute path (e.g. C:\\Users\\You\\data.txt) is independent of where you run from. Wrong path → FileNotFoundError.
**Step 9: Line-by-line loop** — for line in f: reads the file line by line without loading all into memory. line includes the newline. This is a common pattern for large files.
**Key idea:** Open → use (read/write) → close. Use with so close is automatic. Choose the right mode and add \n when writing lines.

with open("example.txt", "r") as f:
    content = f.read()
with open("output.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("first line\n")
    f.write("second line\n")

components.content:
You understand **how** file I/O works — open, modes, cursor, read/write, close, and with.

**Why this matters:** Understanding the process helps you write correct file code and choose the right mode and methods.

**How you'll use this:** Next, you'll **apply** this by writing your own scripts: create a sample file, open with with, read and print, write and append, and verify in the editor or terminal.

You're moving from understanding to **doing**. Now you'll write your own file I/O code. Focus on using with, the right mode, and adding \n when writing lines. Mistakes are normal — that's how you learn!
You understand how open, read, write, close, and with work. Now let's write file code! Can you answer: How do you open for reading? For writing? Why use with?

**Preparation checklist**

✓ Python installed; text editor and terminal ready
✓ A folder for your scripts and sample files
✓ You know strings, loops, and functions
✓ You understand file vocabulary (open, mode, read, write, with)

Once you've checked these, you're ready to write file code!

**Step-by-step: Your first read**

**Step 1:** Create a plain text file (e.g. notes.txt) with 2–3 lines and save it in the same folder as your script.
**Step 2:** Create a new Python file (e.g. file_demo.py).
**Step 3:** Use with open("notes.txt", "r") as f:
**Step 4:** Inside the block: content = f.read() then print(content).
**Step 5:** Run the script from the folder that contains notes.txt; confirm the output.

**Step-by-step: Your first write**

**Step 1:** With the same script (or a new one), use with open("output.txt", "w") as f:
**Step 2:** f.write("Hello\\n"); f.write("World\\n").
**Step 3:** Run the script; open output.txt in an editor and confirm two lines.

**Step-by-step: Append**

**Step 1:** Use with open("output.txt", "a") as f:
**Step 2:** f.write("Appended line\\n").
**Step 3:** Run again; confirm the new line is at the end of output.txt.

**Common pitfalls and how to avoid them**

1. **Wrong mode** — Using "r" when the file doesn't exist → FileNotFoundError. Fix: Use "w" or "a" to create, or check if file exists.
2. **Forgetting newline** — write("line1"); write("line2") → one long line. Fix: write("line1\\n") etc.
3. **Not using with** — Forgetting close() can leak resources. Fix: Prefer with open(...) as f:
4. **Path typo** — Wrong filename or path → FileNotFoundError. Fix: Use the exact path; run from the correct directory.
5. **Reading after full read()** — Second f.read() returns "". Fix: Store result in a variable and reuse it, or open again.
6. **Overwriting with "w"** — "w" wipes the file. Fix: Use "a" if you want to add without losing content.
7. **Encoding** — For non-ASCII text, open(path, "r", encoding="utf-8"). Fix: Specify encoding when needed.
8. **Windows vs Unix paths** — Use "path\\to\\file" or path/to/file; Python accepts forward slashes on Windows too.
9. **Writing then reading same file** — Open with "w", write, then read in same block: read returns "" because cursor is at end. Fix: Close and reopen, or use two with blocks.

**Verification**

• After reading: print the content; check it matches the file.
• After writing: open the file in an editor; confirm lines and newlines.
• Run from the directory that contains the file (or use correct relative/absolute path).

with open("notes.txt", "r") as f:
    text = f.read()
print(text)

with open("output.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write("first\n")
    f.write("second\n")

with open("output.txt", "a") as f:
    f.write("appended\n")

components.content: You can now **write file I/O code** — open with with, read, write, append, and verify. You're ready to **analyze and troubleshoot** when something goes wrong: FileNotFoundError, wrong mode, path issues, and other common file errors.
You're moving from writing correct file code to understanding what goes wrong. Every FileNotFoundError or UnsupportedOperation is a clue. Check path, mode, and whether you closed (or used with).
You know how to read and write files with with. Now we'll look at what happens when it doesn't work — and how to fix it.

**Error taxonomy table (symptom -> likely causes -> verification -> fix)**

| Error Type | Typical Symptom | Likely Causes | Verification Steps | Fix |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| FileNotFoundError | open(path, "r") fails | wrong path, wrong working directory, file missing | print path, check current directory, test absolute path | fix path or create file |
| PermissionError | cannot read/write file | locked file, read-only folder, missing rights | close other app, test writable folder | use writable path or adjust permission |
| IsADirectoryError | tried opening a directory as file | path points to folder not file | inspect path target type | pass a file path instead |
| UnsupportedOperation | read on write-only or write on read-only handle | mode mismatch | inspect open mode and operation | reopen with correct mode |
| UnicodeDecodeError | decode fails during read | wrong encoding assumption | open in editor and inspect encoding | pass explicit encoding |

**Diagnostic flow (use in order):** path -> existence -> permissions -> mode -> encoding.

**Safe test setup before debugging**
- Create a throwaway folder such as `tmp_file_debug`.
- Create small sample files (`ok.txt`, `empty.txt`, `utf8.txt`).
- Run tests only in that folder to avoid accidental overwrite in real files.

**Systematic troubleshooting:** (1) Read exception type and message. (2) Find failing line. (3) Walk the diagnostic flow in order. (4) Re-run with minimal test input. (5) Record evidence: what failed, what changed, what now passes.

# FileNotFoundError: file missing with "r"
# with open("missing.txt", "r") as f:  # fails
# Fix: create file or use "w"/"a"

# UnsupportedOperation: read on "w"
# with open("x.txt", "w") as f:
#     print(f.read())  # fails
# Fix: use "r" to read

components.content:
You can **diagnose and fix** common file errors — FileNotFoundError, wrong mode, path issues, and missing close/with.

**Why this matters:** Debugging file code is a core skill.

**How you'll use this:** Next, you'll **evaluate** what makes file I/O code good — correctness, clarity, safety, and when to use which mode and with.
You're moving from fixing bugs to judging what makes file I/O code good. Focus on correctness, clarity, safety (with, no accidental overwrite), and when to use which mode.
You can diagnose and fix file errors. Now you'll evaluate when file code is well-designed — clear, correct, safe, and appropriate for the task.

**Evaluation criteria rubric**

| Criterion | Strong | Weak |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Safety | uses `with`, avoids accidental overwrite | leaks handles, risky mode choices |
| Reliability | handles expected failure paths | breaks on common edge cases |
| Readability | clear structure and names | unclear intent |
| Data integrity | preserves intended content/newlines | truncates or corrupts data |
| Failure handling | clear strategy for missing/invalid resources | silent failure or confusing behavior |

**When to validate before opening files**
- Validate user-provided path format and expected extension before opening.
- Validate destination policy (overwrite allowed?) before using `w` mode.

**Better vs worse comparisons**

**Write strategy:**
- Worse: always use `w` for logs (can erase history).
- Better: use `a` for logs and `w` only when replacement is intentional.

**Failure handling:**
- Worse: assume file exists and continue after failure.
- Better: define behavior for missing file (prompt, default, or fail clearly).

**Snippet comparison for data integrity:**
- Worse: `f.write("a"); f.write("b")` when line breaks are required.
- Better: `f.write("a\\n"); f.write("b\\n")` with explicit format control.
**Activity 1:** Two snippets. Snippet A: open("data.txt"); read(); no with, no close. Snippet B: with open("data.txt") as f: content = f.read(). Which is better for correctness and safety? Why?

components.content:
You can **evaluate** file I/O design — correctness, clarity, safety, and mode choice.

**Why this matters:** Good file code is maintainable and less error-prone.

**How you'll use this:** Next, you'll **create** your own projects — log writer, config reader, note-taker, report generator — using files. You'll bring together everything you've learned.
You're moving from judging file code to creating your own programs. Design, implement, and test small projects that read and write files to solve real tasks.

You've completed:
- **Remembering** → Vocabulary (open, file object, mode, read, readlines, write, close, with, path)
- **Understanding** → How open, read, write, close, and with work
- **Applying** → Writing file I/O code
- **Analyzing** → Troubleshooting file errors
- **Evaluating** → What makes file code good

Now you'll **create** programs that use files to solve real tasks!

**Project type options**

**1. Log writer** ⭐ — Append a timestamp and message to a log file each time the script runs. Use "a" and write("message\\n").
**2. Config reader** ⭐ — Read a simple .txt config (e.g. key=value per line); print or use the values. Use with and readlines(); split each line.
**3. Simple CSV-style reader** ⭐ — Read a file with comma-separated values (one per line or whole file); split lines and commas; print or process.
**4. Save/load state** ⭐ — Save one list or dict (e.g. as one line per item or simple format); load it back on next run. Use "w" to save, "r" to load.
**5. Note-taking script** ⭐⭐ — Append lines typed by the user (or from input) to a notes.txt file. Use "a" and a loop with input() and write().
**6. Report generator** ⭐⭐ — Build a string (e.g. report) from data (variables, list); write it to a file with "w". Use write() or writelines() with \n.
**7. Line or word counter** ⭐⭐ — Read a file; count lines (len(lines)) or split into words and count; write or print the result.
**8. Combined read–process–write** ⭐⭐ — Read one file, process (e.g. filter or transform lines), write result to another file. Use two with blocks.

**Templates**

**Log writer (Beginner ⭐):**
with open("log.txt", "a") as f:
    f.write("Event: started\\n")

**Config reader (Beginner ⭐):**
with open("config.txt", "r") as f:
    lines = f.readlines()
for line in lines:
    line = line.strip()
    if "=" in line:
        key, value = line.split("=", 1)
        print(key, value)

**Save list to file (Beginner ⭐):**
items = ["a", "b", "c"]
with open("data.txt", "w") as f:
    for item in items:
        f.write(item + "\\n")

**Read list from file (Beginner ⭐):**
with open("data.txt", "r") as f:
    lines = f.readlines()
items = [line.strip() for line in lines]

**Line counter (Intermediate ⭐⭐):**
with open("input.txt", "r") as f:
    lines = f.readlines()
count = len(lines)
with open("result.txt", "w") as f:
    f.write(f"Lines: {count}\\n")

**Success criteria**

• **Log/notes:** Use "a"; write lines with \n.
• **Config/CSV:** Use with and read/readlines(); process lines.
• **Save/load:** Write and read in a consistent format; use "w" to save, "r" to load.
• **Report/counter:** Build content then write with "w"; include newlines.
• **Combined:** Two with blocks (read file, write file); process in between.

components.prompt: What will your program do? (e.g. log writer, config reader, note-taker, report)
Which file(s) will you read and which will you write? What mode (r, w, a) for each?
How will you know it works? (e.g. open the file and check contents)

items: Create a new .py file with a clear name
Use with for all file operations
Use the correct mode (r, w, a) for each file
Add newlines when writing lines
Test with a real file and verify contents
Handle or note missing file if reading

components.content:
**Create a file-based project**

Choose one (or combine):

**Option 1: Log or note-taker** — Append lines to a file; use "a" and write with \n.
**Option 2: Config or CSV reader** — Read a file; process lines; print or use the data.
**Option 3: Save/load state** — Write a list or simple data to a file; read it back on next run.
**Option 4: Report or counter** — Generate content and write to a file; or read, count, write result.

**Quality checklist:** Clear purpose; uses with; correct modes; newlines where needed; tested and verified.

components.instructions: Order these steps for creating your project.
items: Choose what the program will do and which files to read/write
Write the file I/O code with with and correct modes
Test with sample files and verify contents
Fix bugs and add a short comment at the top

components.prompt: Describe your project: what it does, which files it uses, and one design choice you made (e.g. why you used "a" instead of "w").

items: I created a program that reads and/or writes files
My program has a clear purpose and uses with and correct modes
I can explain what each file is for and how I used it
I'm proud of what I built

components.prompt: What did you learn by creating this project? What was hardest? What would you do differently next time?

components.content: You've reached the Creating stage. You've gone from "what is file I/O?" to designing and building file-based programs. You can open, read, write, and close files; use with; choose modes; and troubleshoot errors. You're ready for the next step — like handling errors with exceptions for more robust file handling!

**Journey recap:**

**Stage 0 (Starting)** → What file I/O is and why it matters
**Stage 1 (Remembering)** → Vocabulary: open, file object, mode, read, readlines, write, close, with, path
**Stage 2 (Understanding)** → How open, read, write, close, and with work
**Stage 3 (Applying)** → Writing file I/O code
**Stage 4 (Analyzing)** → Troubleshooting file errors
**Stage 5 (Evaluating)** → What makes file code good
**Stage 6 (Creating)** → Building your own file-based projects

**What's next:**

You have a solid foundation in working with files. Consider learning **errors and exceptions** next so you can handle missing files and permission errors gracefully, and write even more robust programs.
